gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: mig_7series_v4_1_rank_common.

Explanation: This module manages maintenance operations for a memory interface generator (MIG) targeted at 7 series FPGAs. The operations include refresh request handling, ZQ command processing, and self-refresh entry and exit handling for DDR3 memory. Additionally, the module includes a periodic read request feature for refreshing memory content. Each operation has a round-robin arbiter for a fair assignment of maintenance tasks across all memory ranks. The module uses parameters extensively to make it easily adaptable to different configurations.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports:
1. clk: This is the system clock, which orchestrates the operations of the module.
2. rst: This is the system reset signal. It is used to initialize the system and help bring it to a predictable state.
3. init_calib_complete: This input signal indicates whether the initial calibration is complete.
4. app_ref_req: This input signal triggers the refresh request.
5. app_zq_req: This input signal triggers the ZQ calibration command.
6. app_sr_req: This input signal initiates self-refresh request.
7. insert_maint_r1: This input signal is used to trigger the memory maintenance operations.
8. refresh_request: This array (RANKS wide) of input signals is used to trigger a refresh for each rank.
9. maint_wip_r: This input signal indicates a maintenance operation in progress.
10. slot_0_present, slot_1_present: These inputs indicate the presence of the corresponding memory slots.
11. periodic_rd_request: This array (RANKS wide) of input signals is used to trigger periodical read operations for each rank.
12. periodic_rd_ack_r: This input signal acknowledges a periodic read request.

Output ports:
1. maint_prescaler_tick_r: This output signal provides a maintain prescaler tick.
2. refresh_tick: This output signal provides a refresh tick.
3. maint_zq_r: This output signal indicates an ongoing ZQ calibration operation.
4. maint_sre_r: This output signal indicates an ongoing self-refresh entry operation.
5. maint_srx_r: This output signal indicates an ongoing self-refresh exit operation.
6. maint_req_r: This output signal indicates a maintenance request.
7. maint_rank_r: This output signal indicates the rank currently being maintained.
8. clear_periodic_rd_request: This output signal clears the periodic read request.
9. periodic_rd_r: This output signal provides a periodic read request.
10. periodic_rd_rank_r: This output provides the rank for the current periodic read request.
11. app_ref_ack: This output signal acknowledges the refresh request.
12. app_zq_ack: This output signal acknowledges the ZQ calibration request.
13. app_sr_active: This output signal indicates the active self-refresh request.
14. maint_ref_zq_wip: This output signal indicates that a refresh or ZQ calibration operation is ongoing.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
1. Internal signal: ONE. Explanation: A general purpose signal that carries the value of 1, mainly used for increment and decrement operations.
   
2. Internal signal: MAINT_PRESCALER_WIDTH. Explanation: This signal is derived from 'MAINT_PRESCALER_DIV' parameter, representing the width of maintenance prescaler register.
   
3. Internal signal: maint_prescaler_tick_r_lcl. Explanation: This is a local version of the 'maint_prescaler_tick_r' output. It is updated through a synchronous reset and set when 'maint_prescaler_r' equals "1".
   
4. Internal signal: maint_prescaler_r and maint_prescaler_ns. Explanation: They are used in the generate block 'maint_prescaler'. They record the current and next state of the maintenance prescaler.
   
5. Internal signal: clogb2. Explanation: A function which calculates the ceil(log2(size)) which is then used for calculating widths of several registers.
   
6. Internal signal: REFRESH_TIMER_WIDTH. Explanation: This signal is derived from 'REFRESH_TIMER_DIV' parameter, representing the width of refresh timer register.
   
7. Internal signal: refresh_tick_lcl. Explanation: A local version of the 'refresh_tick' output. It represents the refresh timer tick.

8. Internal signal: maint_arb0. Explanation: Instance of the round-robin arbiter for distributing maintenance tasks fairly among all memory ranks.
   
9. Internal signal: periodic_rd_r_cnt, periodic_rd_grant_r, periodic_rd_rank_ns and periodic_rd_arb0. Explanation: These signals are part of the generate block 'periodic_read_request', which manages the periodic read requests to the memory system.
   
10. Internal signal: maint_ref_zq_wip_r. Explanation: This signal indicates whether a refresh procedure or ZQ calibration procedure is underway. It is the local version of the output 'maint_ref_zq_wip'.
